{{Infobox football biography | name = Clint Dempsey | image = [[File:Clint Dempsey 20110622.jpg|200px]] | caption = Clint Dempsey, representing the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] at the [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup]] semi-final match against [[Panama national football team|Panama]] | fullname = Clinton Drew Dempsey | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1983|3|9}} | birth_place = [[Nacogdoches, Texas]], [[United States]] | height = {{convert|1.85|m|ftin|abbr=on}}<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.premierleague.com/page/PlayerProfile/0,,12306~38223,00.html| title = Premier League Player Profile | accessdate = 18 March 2011 | publisher = Premier League}}</ref> | currentclub = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] | position = [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|Attacking Midfielder]], [[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]], [[Forward_(football)#Striker|Striker]] | clubnumber = 23 | youthyears1 = 1998â2001 | youthyears2 = 2001â2003 | youthclubs1 = [[Dallas Texans (youth soccer)|Dallas Texans]] | youthclubs2 = [[Furman University|Furman Paladins]] | years1 = 2004â2006 | years2 = 2007â | clubs1 = [[New England Revolution]] | clubs2 = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] | caps1 = 71 | caps2 = 160 | goals1 = 25 | goals2 = 36 | nationalyears1 = 2004â | nationalteam1 = [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] | nationalcaps1 = 82 | nationalgoals1 = 24 | pcupdate = 20:00, 26 November 2011 (UTC) | ntupdate = 21:00, November 20, 2011 (UTC) }}
'''Clinton Drew "Clint" Dempsey''' (born March 9, 1983) is an [[United States|American]] soccer player who plays for [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] and the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States national team]]. Dempsey usually plays as either an [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]], or a striker.
Growing up in [[Nacogdoches, Texas]], Dempsey played for one of the top state youth soccer clubs, the [[Dallas Texans]] before playing for Furman University's men's soccer team. In 2004, Dempsey was drafted by the [[Major League Soccer]] club, [[New England Revolution]], where he quickly integrated himself into the starting lineup. Hindered initially by a jaw injury, he would score seven goals in 24 appearances with the Revolution. Since 2007, Dempsey has played for [[Premier league]] team [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] and has become the club's Premier League record goalscorer.
Dempsey first represented the United States at the [[2003 FIFA World Youth Championship]] in the United Arab Emirates. He made his first appearance with the senior team on November 17, 2004 against Jamaica, and was named in the squad for the 2006 World Cup, scoring the teams only goal of the tournament. Dempsey recorded the fastest goal in U.S. World Cup qualifying history by scoring after 53 seconds into a 8-0 defeat of Barbados. In the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]], Dempsey scored against England, becoming the third American, after [[Brian McBride]] and [[Landon Donovan]], to score goals in multiple World Cup tournaments.
==Youth== Dempsey was born in [[Nacogdoches]], [[Texas]] and, for much of his childhood, his family lived in a [[trailer park]], where he and his siblings grew up playing soccer with the local children or anyone he could find. His older brother [[Ryan Dempsey|Ryan]] was offered a tryout for the [[Dallas Texans Soccer Club|Dallas Texans]], an elite youth soccer club, but young Clint, who had come along, was noticed and recruited while passing time juggling a ball on the sidelines.<ref>{{cite news| title=Quite a trip for U.S. midfielder|author=Hairopoulos, Kate|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/soccer/worldcup/stories/060806dnspocuplede.1cd47fa2.html|date=June 8, 2006|accessdate=July 14, 2006|work=[[The Dallas Morning News]]}}</ref> Dempsey became a standout on the team at an early age, but had to quit due to his family's time and money constraints as his eldest sister Jennifer was becoming a ranked youth [[tennis]] player.<ref name="espn1">{{cite news|author=Drehs, Wayne | url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=370300 | title=No ordinary background | publisher=[[Soccernet|ESPN Soccernet]] | date=June 8, 2006 | accessdate=June 22, 2006}}</ref> But several parents of his teammates with the Texans offered to assist the Dempseys with expenses and travel, allowing him to rejoin the club.
He went on to be the captain and high scorer of the Texans and was honored with MVP in the Tampa Bay Sun Bowl tournament. He was offered a place in the youth Arsenal team but because cousin Arya Ashtari was severely ill, he had to move on from the Arsenal academy. Dempsey studied the play of [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]], especially [[Diego Maradona]]. Clint was heartbroken when the news came to Nacogdoches that Maradona would not be playing in the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994 World Cup]] game played in the [[Cotton Bowl (stadium)|Cotton Bowl]].<ref name="espn2">{{cite news|author=Connolly, Marc|title=Rookie of the year is still a rookie|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=324350|date=February 7, 2005|accessdate=July 14, 2006|work=[[Soccernet|ESPNSoccernet]]}}</ref> He attended [[Furman University]] as a health and exercise major and a key player for the Paladins. In his three seasons at Furman, Dempsey started 61 out of 62 games in central midfield and scored 17 goals.
==Club career== ===New England Revolution=== [[New England Revolution]] selected Clint Dempsey 8th overall in the 2004 MLS SuperDraft. His rookie season he started 23 of 24 matches scoring 7 goals. Dempsey helped the Revolution to the Eastern Conference Finals and earned 2004 MLS Rookie of the Year Honors. In 2005 Dempsey scored 10 goals and added 9 assists in 26 games. He scored the game winning goal in the Eastern Conference Final on the way to the MLS Cup Final. The following year Dempsey added 8 more goals in 2006 but missed significant time in the playoffs due to injury. He came on as a substitute in the MLS Cup Final but the Revolution lost their second straight final this time on penalties.
=== Fulham === ==== 2007â2009 ==== [[File:Clint.JPG|295px|thumb|Dempsey training with Fulham in August 2009]] In December 2006, English club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] offered the MLS [[United States dollar|$]]4 million for the transfer of Dempsey, then the largest amount ever offered for an MLS player.<ref>{{cite news |first=Frank |last=Dell'Apa |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=398831&root=mls&cc=5901 |title=Dempsey could set the tone for future MLS transfers |work=ESPNsoccernet |publisher=ESPNs |date=7 January 2007 |accessdate=7 January 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Frank |last=Dell'Apa |url=http://www.boston.com/sports/soccer/articles/2007/02/27/transfer_of_power_for_revolution/ |title=Transfer of power for Revolution |work=Boston.com |publisher=The Boston Globe |date=27 February 2007 |accessdate=27 February 2007}}</ref> On 11 January 2007, he was granted a work permit from the [[Home Office]] as Fulham announced his signing on a long-term deal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/Club/News/NewsArticles/2007/January/Dempseysigns.aspx |title=Transfer of power for Revolution |work=FulhamFC.com |publisher=Fulham FC |date=11 January 2007 |accessdate=11 January 2007}}</ref> This made Dempsey the most expensive US export to the [[Premier League]] in a deal worth a reported [[Pound sterling|Â£]]2 million.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/f/fulham/6249567.stm |title=Fulham complete Dempsey transfer |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=11 January 2007 |accessdate=11 January 2007}}</ref> He made his Fulham debut in a 1â1 home draw against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] on 20 January.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=199321&cc=5739 |title=Fulham 1-1 Tottenham |work=ESPNsoccernet |publisher=ESPN |date=20 January 2007 |accessdate=20 January 2007}}</ref> His [[FA Cup]] debut followed seven days later in a 3â0 home win over [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=212859&cc=5739 |title=Fulham 3-0 Stoke City |work=ESPNsoccernet |publisher=ESPN |date=27 January 2007 |accessdate=27 January 2007}}</ref> Dempsey scored his first goal for Fulham on 5 May as he struck the only goal of a 1â0 home win over [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Sinnott |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/6602879.stm |title=Fulham 1-0 Liverpool |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=5 May 2007 |accessdate=5 May 2007}}</ref> This goal saved Fulham from relegation and effectively guaranteed their place in the top-flight for the following season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/Club/News/NewsArticles/2007/May/DempseyGoal.aspx |title=Dempsey's Golden Goal |work=FulhamFC.com |publisher==Fulham FC |date=8 May 2007 |accessdate=8 May 2007}}</ref>
On 25 August, Dempsey scored his first goal of the [[2007â08 Premier League|2007â08 season]] in a 2â1 away loss to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Ben |last=Dirs |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/6952877.stm |title=Aston Villa 2-1 Fulham |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=25 August 2007 |accessdate=25 August 2007}}</ref> He followed this up by scoring in Fulham's next fixture in a 3â3 home draw against Tottenham on 1 September.<ref>{{cite news |first=Nathan |last=Mercer |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/6963700.stm |title=Fulham 3-3 Tottenham |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=1 September 2007 |accessdate=1 September 2007}}</ref> Two weeks later he opened the scoring in Fulham's 1â1 away draw against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/6984886.stm |title=Wigan 1-1 Fulham |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=15 September 2007 |accessdate=15 September 2007}}</ref> These goals gave Dempsey three in as many games after Fulham manager [[Lawrie Sanchez]]'s decision to convert Dempsey into a [[Forward (association football)|striker]] following an injury to compatriot [[Brian McBride]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/Club/News/NewsArticles/2007/September/DempseyEnjoy.aspx |title=Leading the Line |work=FulhamFC.com |publisher=Fulham FC |date=18 September 2007 |accessdate=18 September 2007}}</ref> On 29 September, Dempsey was involved in an aerial collision with [[John Terry]] during a 0â0 draw at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] which resulted in Terry being substituted.<ref>{{cite news |first=Paresh |last=Soni |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7008196.stm |title=Chelsea 0-0 Fulham |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=29 September 2007 |accessdate=29 September 2007}}</ref> There was some suggestion that Dempsey used a deliberate elbow on Terry,<ref>{{cite news |first=Matt |last=Lawton |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-484872/FA-urged-charge-Dempsey-Terry.html |title=FA urged to charge Dempsey over Terry |work=the Daily Mail |publisher=Associated Newspapers Ltd |date=30 September 2007 |accessdate=30 September 2007}}</ref> however, he wasn't punished for the incident as referee [[Martin Atkinson]] didn't report it to the [[Football Association]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/7020122.stm |title=Terry to lead Chelsea in Valencia |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=3 October 2007 |accessdate=3 October 2007}}</ref> On 3 November, Dempsey scored during Fulham's 3â1 home win over [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] to secure just a second league win of the season.<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Sinnott |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7065158.stm |title=Fulham 3-1 Reading |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=3 November 2007 |accessdate=3 November 2007}}</ref> He scored his last goals of the season in a 1â1 home draw with [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] and 5â1 away loss to Tottenham in December.<ref>{{cite news |first=Sam |last=Lyon |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7145744.stm |title=Wigan 1-1 Fulham |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=22 December 2007 |accessdate=22 December 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Sam |last=Lyon |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7157358.stm |title=Tottenham 5-1 Fulham |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=26 December 2007 |accessdate=26 December 2007}}</ref> In May 2008, Fulham announced Dempsey had signed a contract extension which will keep him at the club until the summer of 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/Club/News/NewsArticles/2008/May/DempseySignsExtension.aspx |title=Dempsey Signs Extension |work=FulhamFC.com |publisher=Fulham FC |date=3 May 2008 |accessdate=3 May 2008}}</ref> Fulham beat Portsmouth 1â0 on the final day of the season to secure Premier League status for another year.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Hughes |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7381800.stm |title=Portsmouth 0-1 Fulham |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=11 May 2008 |accessdate=11 May 2008}}</ref> He ended the season as Fulham's top Premier League goalscorer with six goals.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=1055&season_id=137#teamTabs=stats |title=Fulham Player Stats 2007/08 |work=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm Ltd |date=15 May 2011 |accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
Dempsey scored his first goal of the [[2008â09 Premier League|2008â09 season]] in a 1â1 away draw at [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] on 26 October.<ref>{{cite news |first=Nabil |last=Hassan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7674167.stm |title=Portsmouth 1-1 Fulham |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=26 October 2008 |accessdate=26 October 2008}}</ref> His first home goal of the season came in a 3â0 win over [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] on 20 December.<ref>{{cite news |first=Saj |last=Chowdhury |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7775562.stm |title=Fulham 3-0 Middlesbrough |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=20 December 2008 |accessdate=20 December 2008}}</ref> Eight days later he scored twice in the [[West London derby]] against Chelsea which included a last-minute equaliser in a 2â2 home draw.<ref>{{cite news |first=Jonathan |last=Stevenson |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7788414.stm |title=Fulham 2-2 Chelsea |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=28 December 2008 |accessdate=28 December 2008}}</ref> On 24 February 2009, Dempsey scored the first FA Cup goal of his career in a 2â1 home win over [[Swansea City F.C.|Swansea City]] in the fifth-round.<ref>{{cite news |first=Peter |last=Shuttleworth |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/7899650.stm |title=Fulham 2-2 Chelsea |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=24 February 2009 |accessdate=24 February 2009}}</ref> His final home goal of the season came in a 2â1 defeat to [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on 11 March.<ref>{{cite news |first=Marc |last=Vesty |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7922053.stm |title=Fulham 1-2 Blackburn |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=11 March 2009 |accessdate=11 March 2009}}</ref> Fulham came from a goal down to beat [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] 3â1 away from home as Dempsey scored two goals on 12 April.<ref>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7978876.stm |title=Man City 1-3 Fulham |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=12 April 2009 |accessdate=12 April 2009}}</ref> For the second successive season, Dempsey ended as Fulham's top Premier League goalscorer joint with [[Andrew Johnson (English footballer)|Andrew Johnson]] with seven goals.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=1055&season_id=138#teamTabs=stats |title=Fulham Player Stats 2008/09 |work=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm Ltd |date=15 May 2011 |accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref> These goals helped Fulham secure a seventh-place finish in the Premier League, the highest in the clubs history, and confirmed their qualification for the newly formed [[UEFA Europa League]] for the following season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/MatchAndTeam/MatchCentre/Matches/0809/Premiership/EvertonHome.aspx |title=Fulham v Everton |work=FulhamFC.com |publisher=Fulham FC |date=24 May 2009 |accessdate=24 May 2009}}</ref>
==== 2009â10 season ==== On August 13, 2009, Dempsey signed a contract extension to remain with Fulham through 2013.<ref> {{Cite document |title=Dempsey Signs Extension |url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/Club/News/NewsArticles/2009/August/DempseyExtension.aspx |publisher=Fulham FC|date=August 13, 2009|accessdate=August 13, 2009|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> On August 20, he scored his first goal in European competition, in the newly formed [[UEFA Europa League|Europa League]], netting Fulham's second goal in a 3â1 win against [[FC Amkar Perm|Amkar Perm]] in the [[2009â10 UEFA Europa League qualifying phase and play-off round#Play-off round|play-off]] round.<ref>{{Cite document |title= Fulham 3â1 Amkar Perm |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/8209325.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=August 20, 2009|accessdate=August 20, 2009|postscript= <!--None-->}}</ref> On December 30, ''[[La Gazzetta dello Sport]]'' named Dempsey as one of the top eleven Premier League players of the season.<ref>{{Cite document |last=Cantalupi |first=Stefano |title=I verdetti di metÃ Premier Ancelotti gira in testa |url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Estero/Premierleague/29-12-2009/i-verdetti-meta-premier-602478747237.shtml |publisher=''[[La Gazzetta dello Sport]]'' |date=December 30, 2009 |accessdate=January 5, 2010|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> On January 17, 2010, Dempsey suffered a suspected [[cruciate ligament|cruciate knee ligament]] injury in a 2â0 away defeat to [[Blackburn Rovers]].<ref>{{Cite document |title=Fulham's Clint Dempsey knee injury rocks Fulham and US |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/f/fulham/8464490.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=January 17, 2010|accessdate=January 17, 2010 |postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> On March 11, Dempsey returned, coming on in the last minute of Fulham's loss away to [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] and then completed 72 minutes of their away loss to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in the league.<ref>{{Cite document |title=How do Fulham stop Wayne Rooney? Easy, we've got Brede Hangeland and Aaron Hughes! Confident Paul Konchesky looking forward to Manchester United test |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1257640/How-Fulham-stop-Wayne-Rooney-Easy-weve-got-Brede-Hangeland-Aaron-Hughes-Confident-Paul-Konchesky-looking-forward-Manchester-United-test.html |publisher=Mail Online|date=March 13, 2010|accessdate=March 13, 2010|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> On March 18, Dempsey came off the bench against Juventus in their second leg last 16 tie in the Europa League and scored the winner on a long chip shot. Fulham won the game 4-1 and this game awarded Fulham an award, as well as Dempsey receiving an award from his 'Wonderful' (Quote from the commentator on ESPN) goal.<ref>{{Cite document |title=Fulham 4â1 Juventus |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/8573049.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=March 18, 2010|accessdate=March 18, 2010|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'' suggested that the goal "might become the most famous goal in Fulham's history".<ref>{{Cite document |title=Fulham's Clint Dempsey gambles to knock Juventus out of Europa League |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2010/mar/19/fulham-juventus-europa-league |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=March 19, 2010|accessdate=March 19, 2010|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> On May 12, Dempsey replaced [[Bobby Zamora]] in the 55th minute of the [[2010 UEFA Europa League Final]], thus making history in becoming the first ever American to appear in a major European final. In the end, Fulham lost the match, as [[AtlÃ©tico Madrid]]'s [[Diego ForlÃ¡n]] scored in the 116th minute of [[extra time]], giving AtlÃ©tico a 2â1 win.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Clint Dempsey Becomes First American To Appear In European Final |url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/1614/americans-abroad/2010/05/12/1922167/clint-dempsey-becomes-first-american-to-appear-in-european |publisher=Goal.com |date=May 12, 2010|accessdate=May 12, 2010|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> His performances throughout 2009â10 earned him the designation of Most Valuable Player among Americans in Europe by SoccerOverThere.com, among other sources.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Howieâs 2009â10 All-Over There team|url=http://www.socceroverthere.com/?p=1303 |publisher=SoccerOverThere.com |date=May 3, 2010|accessdate=May 3, 2010|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref>
==== 2010â11 season ==== Dempsey remained a regular starter, one of only five Americans in the Premier League to do so currently. On 18 September 2010, he scored an equalising goal on 56 minutes with a header against [[Blackburn Rovers]] at [[Ewood Park]] in the 1-1 draw and continue Fulham's undefeated streak in the Barclays Premier League.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9000608.stm|title=Blackburn 1â1 Fulham|publisher=BBC Sport|date=September 18, 2010}}</ref> On October 2, he scored against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] past [[Robert Green]], the same keeper that he had scored against in the World Cup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/premier-league/7943457/West-Ham-United-1-Fulham-1-match-report.html|title=West Ham United 1 Fulham 1: match report|publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=October 2, 2010|date=October 2, 2010}}</ref> He then continued his form by scoring two goals against Wigan Athletic on October 30 as Fulham ran out 2 â 0 winners.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccer.fanhouse.com/2010/10/30/video-clint-dempsey-scores-twice-for-fulham-on-big-day-for-amer/|title=Clint Dempsey Scores Twice for Fulham on Big Day for Americans Abroad|publisher=FanHouse.com|date=October 30, 2010|accessdate=October 30, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2010/oct/30/fulham-wigan-athletic-premier-league|title=Fulham ease past woeful Wigan Athletic thanks to Clint Dempsey double|publisher=The Guardian|date=October 30, 2010|accessdate=October 30, 2010}}</ref> On January 22, Dempsey scored another double versus [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke]], putting Fulham temporarily out of relegation contention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9362434.stm|title=Fulham 2 - 0 Stoke|publisher=BBC Sport|date=22 January 2011|accessdate=22 January 2011}}</ref> ''
On March 19, Dempsey became the first American to score 10 goals in a Premier League season, beating [[Brian McBride]]'s previous record of nine, also set while at Fulham in the 2005-06 season and 2006-07 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://goal.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/03/19/yanks-abroa-dempsey-sets-a-record/|title=Yanks Abroad: Dempsey Sets a Record; Holden Hurt|publisher= The New York Times|date=March 19, 2011|accessdate=March 20, 2011}}</ref>
Clint Dempsey broke Fulham's Premier League goalscoring record by netting twice in a 3-0 victory over Bolton on April 27, 2011. He has scored a total of 33 goals for the team in the Premier League, topping both Brian McBride and [[Steed Malbranque]], each with 32. With these goals, he has now scored 12 goals for Fulham in the 2010-11 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-04-27/fulham-beats-bolton-3-0-to-pull-clear-of-premier-league-s-relegation-zone.html |title=Fulham Beats Bolton 3-0 to Pull Clear of Premier League's Relegation Zone|publisher=Bloomberg|date=April 27, 2011|accessdate=April 28, 2011}}</ref>
At the end of the season, Dempsey was voted Fulham player of the season by Fulham fans.
==== 2011-12 season ==== Dempsey marked his return to the first team by scoring a brace in the first leg of their [[2011-12 UEFA Europa League qualifying phase and play-off round|Europa League play-off]] clash against [[Dnipro Dnipropetrovsk]] at Craven Cottage. Dempsey ended with two goals as Fulham ran out 3-0 winners, setting up a comfortable second leg in Ukraine.<ref>http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=328073&cc=5901</ref>
==International career== [[File:Clint Dempsey USA training.jpg|thumb|upright|Dempsey training with the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] in April 2006]] Dempsey first played for the [[United States men's national soccer team|American national team]] at the [[2003 FIFA World Youth Championship]] in the [[United Arab Emirates]]. He made his first appearance with the senior team on November 17, 2004 against [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]]. He has frequently lined up as a [[striker]] due to his scoring threat and aerial ability, but his preferred and more normal role is on the wing. He won the highest individual honor in American soccer when he was named [[Honda Player of the Year]] for 2006, beating Fulham teammates [[Kasey Keller]] and [[Brian McBride]] in a poll of sportswriters. Dempsey received 237 points in voting by 207 sports journalists to claim the award.
On May 2, 2006, Dempsey was named to the U.S. roster for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 tournament]] in [[Germany]]. He was the only American player to score a goal in the tournament<ref>{{Cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]] |author=Blum, Ronald |title=Dempsey a rare American soccer attacker |work=[[Yahoo! Sports]] |url=http://sports.yahoo.com/sow/news?slug=ap-us-dempsey&prov=ap&type=lgns |date=Junecc2, 2009|accessdate=June 2, 2009}}</ref> with his equalizing goal in the Americans' eventual 2â1 loss to [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]].
In the United States' opening [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 World Cup]] qualifier, Dempsey recorded the fastest goal in U.S. qualifying history with a chest trap and sliding shot 53 seconds into a 8â0 defeat of [[Barbados national football team|Barbados]]. But thereafter, Dempsey experienced a dip in form leading some to doubt his first-choice status with the national team. However, Dempsey turned his fortunes around in the [[2009 FIFA Confederations Cup]]. In the final group stage match against [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]], Dempsey scored a trademark diving header off a [[Jonathan Spector]] cross, making the final result 3â0. This, combined with Brazil's 3â0 victory against [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in the other group match that was being played simultaneously, put the U.S. through to the semifinals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/8109905.stm|title= Egypt 0â3 USA |date=June 21, 2009|work=BBC Sport|accessdate= June 25, 2009}}</ref> In the semi-final match against [[Spain national football team|Spain]], Dempsey scored to put the USA up 2â0 to send them to the finals. He was named the [[Man of the Match]] for his performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/8114585.stm|title= Spain 0â2 United States |date=June 25, 2009|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=June 25, 2009}}</ref> Dempsey scored in his third straight game in the [[2009 FIFA Confederations Cup Final|Confederations Cup Final]] against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]], redirecting a similar cross from Spector in the 10th minute to open the scoring.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/8120561.stm |title=USA 2â3 Brazil |date=June 28, 2009|work=BBC Sport |accessdate=June 28, 2009}}</ref> Following the loss, he was awarded the Bronze Ball as the tournament's 3rd best performer.<ref>{{Cite news |first=Amelia |last=Templeton |title=U.S. Men's Soccer Team Takes Second in Confederations Cup: Goalie Howard, Defender Onyewu's Head lead the US effort to stop Brazil |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/amelia-templeton/us-mens-soccer-team-takes_b_222055.html |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=June 28, 2009|accessdate=June 30, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |first=Ridge |last=Mahoney |title=Emotions tell the tale of dramatic final |url=http://www.socceramerica.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=Articles.showArticleHomePage&art_aid=32945 |work=[[Soccer America]] |date=June 29, 2009|accessdate=June 30, 2009}}</ref> He ended the World Cup qualifying campaign tied with [[Landon Donovan]] as the team's 2nd top scorer, behind [[Jozy Altidore]], with five goals in thirteen matches.
On June 12, 2010, Dempsey became the second American (after Brian McBride) to score in more than one World Cup when he scored the equalizer goal against England in the Americans' first game of the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 World Cup]] after the West Ham and English goalkeeper [[Robert Green]] made a major error.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/37660344/ns/sports-world_cup/ | title=U.S. strikes back, earns draw with England | publisher=[[Associated Press]] | first=Ronald | last=Blum | date=June 12, 2010 | accessdate=July 7, 2010}}</ref>

==Playing style== Known for his toughness, Dempsey played two games with a broken [[jaw]] in 2004 before the team trainer diagnosed it, and upon his return, he played through the pain of a sprained [[ankle]]. Despite usually playing in wide positions, he frequently scores close-range goals and has scored repeatedly with diving headers in crowded situations. His tenacity in midfield combined with his audacious [[dribbling]] skills frequently results in opponents fouling him, and Dempsey has gained a reputation for fierce play. He was suspended by the [[New England Revolution]] for two weeks in March 2006 for a fist fight with teammate [[Joe Franchino]] during a practice game<ref name="espn1" /> and was twice suspended by MLS during the 2006 season for violent conduct against opponents, including an elbow that broke the jaw of national teammate [[Jimmy Conrad]]. In a similar incident with Fulham in 2007, Dempsey broke the cheekbone of [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] defender [[John Terry]] in an aerial challenge but was not penalized.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dempsey not a dirty player, says Sanchez|work=Mail Online|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-484991/Dempsey-dirty-player-says-Sanchez-Terry-foul.html|date=October 1, 2007|accessdate=December 4, 2009}}</ref>
Dempsey is a versatile attacking midfielder normally played on the left or right for Fulham and the United States. However, he has proven to be more of a threat the closer to goal he gets. His goals against Egypt and Spain in the Confederations Cup came almost immediately after being moved to forward by a substitution from [[Bob Bradley]].

==Personal life== Dempsey is married to Bethany Keegan Dempsey. They have a daughter named Elyse and a son named Jackson.They live in Wimbledon and Clint loves to play golf.
===Music=== One of Dempsey's passions outside of football is [[hip hop music]]. Using the alias "Deuce," he, along with fellow Texas rappers [[XO]] and the late Houston rapper [[Big Hawk]] from the Screwed Up Click, are featured rapping the song "Don't Tread" in a [[Nike Inc.|Nike]] football advertising campaign for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]] with the intention to showcase both the sport's working-class roots and the United States team ahead of the World Cup.<ref>{{cite news|title=Don't Tread on Clint|author=Carlisle, Jeff|date=February 7, 2006|accessdate=July 14, 2006|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=357903|work=[[Soccernet|ESPN Soccernet]]}}</ref> The song's video is dedicated to his sister Jennifer, who, at age sixteen, was suddenly struck with a fatal [[brain aneurysm]]. At Dempsey's request, the video ends with a shot of him placing a flower at her grave.<ref name="espn1" />
